explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: No data available. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2075) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing oxygen and chlorine (but not fluorine), with the oxygen and chlorine bound to carbon and hydrogen respectively (but not to other elements)

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Those containing stabilizers are classified into Division 6.1 (UN#2075) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 480mg/kg (CICAD 25 (2000)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the guinea pig LD50 (dermal route) value of 1,510mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 1,510mg/kg and 15,000mg/kg (CERI Hazard Data 2000-52 (2001)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 value of 0.44mg/L (equivalent to 73ppm), representing the lower of the two testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour) of 2.12mg/L (4 hours) (CERI Hazard Data 2000-52 (2001)) and 0.44mg/L (MOE Risk Assessment vol. 3 (2004)), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (47,000ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 4.7kPa (20degC) (CERI Hazard Data 2000-52 (2001)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description of the human health effects (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.97 (2004)): "Chloral hydrate has a potential for skin and mucosal irritation, and at clinical doses, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting may occur." The substance is thus considered a skin irritant, but classified into Category 3 in the absence of data on the degree of irritation. According to NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.97 (2005), "trichloroacetaldehyde rapidly reacts in vivo with water to form chloral hydrate." However, only those studies specifying "trichloroacetaldehyde" as the test material were used as a basis for classification.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description of the human health effects (CERI-NITE Hazard Assessment No.97 (2004)): "Chloral hydrate has a potential for skin and mucosal irritation, and at clinical doses, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting may occur." The substance is thus considered a skin irritant, but classified into Category 2B in the absence of data on the degree of irritation. According to NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.97 (2005), "trichloroacetaldehyde rapidly reacts in vivo with water to form chloral hydrate." However, only those studies specifying "trichloroacetaldehyde" as the test material were used as a basis for classification.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests and positive data on germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo (micronucleus tests), described in NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.97 (2005), NTP DB (Access on April 2006) and IARC 63 (1995).

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Group 3 (CHLORAL AND CHLORAL HYDRATE) by IARC (2004).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence of learning deficits in the offspring, described in MOE Risk Assessment vol. 2 (2003), CICAD 25 (2000) and IARC 63 (1995), though no data are available regarding the general conditions of parental animals.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (respiratory system) May cause drowsiness or dizziness (narcotic effects)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the evidence from animal studies including "strong narcotic effects, vacuolization of Clara cells, alveolar necrosis, epithelial exfoliation and alveolar edema" (NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.97 (2005)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
According to NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.97 (2005), "trichloroacetaldehyde rapidly reacts in vivo with water to form chloral hydrate." However, only those studies specifying "trichloroacetaldehyde" as the test material were used as a basis for classification.

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.rationale:
Classification not possible due to the insufficiency of data.
According to NITE Initial Risk Assessment No.97 (2005), "trichloroacetaldehyde rapidly reacts in vivo with water to form chloral hydrate." However, only those studies specifying "trichloroacetaldehyde" as the test material were used as a basis for classification.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Not classified from 48 hours EC50=112mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (CERI/NITE Hazard Assessment Report (2005) and others.).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since it was not water-insolubility (the water-solubility =30000mg/L (PHYSPROP Database, 2005)), and acute toxicity was low, it was classified into Not classified.
